timeline.bodyText:
A service should be able to handle multiple GS messages.
Why is a GS implementation tied to a GS message here?
timeline.author: xieus

replies.bodyText:
service IS able to handle multiple in parallel, we would use multiple service instance in thread level to make sure performance and secure, if only use service handle multiple GS messages which is later on done on the blockingstub way of grpc, it would anyway block others due to thread safety, please refer to fa26821 and here is the log when paralleling call:
Client1 call:
Thread[pool-1-thread-2,5,main] 1.2.3.6
Thread[pool-1-thread-3,5,main] 1.2.3.4
2020-06-11 01:46:05.971  INFO 22260 --- [pool-1-thread-3] global                                   : GoalStateProvisionerClient : Will try to send GS with fast path...
2020-06-11 01:46:05.971  INFO 22260 --- [pool-1-thread-2] global                                   : GoalStateProvisionerClient : Will try to send GS with fast path...
At the same time Client2 call:
Thread[pool-1-thread-1,5,main] 10.213.43.187
2020-06-11 01:46:05.969  WARN 22260 --- [pool-1-thread-1] global                                   : Failed: Log Configuration
2020-06-11 01:46:05.969  INFO 22260 --- [pool-1-thread-1] global                                   : GoalStateProvisionerClient : Will try to send GS with fast path...
replies.author: haboy52581

replies.author: haboy52581

timeline.bodyText: Say gss have multiple goal state messages, if we only have one single goalStateService, its setGoalState   method would overwrite its internal goalstate, which could interference with goal state messages, i.e., no parallelism is supported. Is it right?
timeline.author: xieus

replies.bodyText: @haboy52581 This is quite significant. Please take a look.
replies.author: xieus

replies.bodyText:
As mentioned above, service IS able to handle multiple in parallel, we would use multiple service instance in thread level to make sure performance and secure, if only use service handle multiple GS messages which is later on done on the blockingstub way of grpc, it would anyway block others due to thread safety, please refer to fa26821 and here is the log when paralleling call:

timeline.bodyText: Do we need to consider port ip and mac when checking equality?
timeline.author: xieus

replies.bodyText:
i think it depends on our req, e.g if we have same portid, should we consider same port?
same portid would have different portIp or mac?
replies.author: haboy52581

replies.bodyText:
One port id could have multiple port Ips (that is where the fixedIP plays a role) but always with the same mac address.
This doesn't matter here though as we want to compare all fields of two objects fairly. @haboy52581

timeline.bodyText:
@haboy52581 Return a "handmade" results like this basically return 200 SUCCUSS to upstream microservice which is not expected.
Instead, we should look deep into possible exceptions, and use different error codes for different exceptions.
One example is Port Manager which has a full list of home-grown exceptions https://github.com/futurewei-cloud/alcor/tree/master/services/port_manager/src/main/java/com/futurewei/alcor/portmanager/exception
Please check its implementation carefully and see if we can do the same here.

replies.author: haboy52581

replies.bodyText:
I didn't suggest we have to use List. The comment refers to that if we need the conversion or not.
This type of conversion is not free and requires overhead of copying memory from one place to the other. If it is absolutely needed, of course we should keep it as is. Is it the case here?

replies.bodyText: I think we could leave it for now since in the following code there are codes relying on the array which is easier than arraylist as well, and we could not get any benefits to use from arraylist.

timeline.message: change jdk1.8 to 11 and format code

timeline.bodyText:
The DPM UTs currently cover the GSManager only. We will also need to cover the controller layer and others.
Please leverage the code coverage report to cover more core logic: https://codecov.io/gh/futurewei-cloud/alcor/tree/f0bcc66f4256ffb75859fc91019bf56bbd68629d/services/data_plane_manager/src/main/java/com/futurewei/alcor/dataplane
Create a tracking issue #288.
timeline.author: xieus
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,4573 @@
+package com.futurewei.alcor.dataplane.utils;
